number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Antichamber. It looks and sounds so simplistic. But it isn't.Antichamber is a puzzle game that challenges your mind. What seems simple isn't so, and what seems complicated is easy. Return to places different than you remember. All of what Antichamber is as a game, is to screw you mentally. That's why I love it.You are in a pseudo-sensory-deprivation chamber. You navigate your way through a simple world. W for forward.A for left. But wait. It gets way more complicated. Some pathways are straightforward and simple. Some require meticulous observation. Some require you to take a step back, look in a certain area, move in a certain way. As the game moves forward, the complexity increases.Pick up and move blocks.Solve puzzles.Turn around.Shift blocks forward.Destroy them.Multiply them. Fly. Soon, your ability augments even more: you learn more new tricks, but continue to use the old. Swap perspectives. Expand.Solve.Extract.And finally, presented with the final problem. you need to outsmart it. You need to use everything you know, from the basic WASD and jump, to the complex techniques that you have learned from the Manipulator. To destroy the final dark force. To escape.10/10 - IGN.While I wouldn't say it has too much replayability, it certainly is possible. It's fun! You can stretch your brain to its limits, and spend hours upon hous figuring out one piece to the worldly puzzle. It has a pretty short campaign, though the speed all depends on how fast it takes you to figure out each puzzle. There are hidden secrets in-game, hidden perspectives, and hidden meanings. Pick up this game now, and understand everything!Explore. Play. Observe. Destroy. Antichamber.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												When I saw screenshots, the game did not seem to be of much interest to me, especially because I don't like puzzle games.I did enjoy Portal though, so I decided to give Antichamber a go. This game has no story, and a very simplistic visuals. Audio does add to the atmosphere though. The game begins with extremely easy tasks, but the difficulty slowly raises the further you go. What surprised me is that this is not a portal clone at all, whatever screenshots suggest, but it's a puzzle game nonetheless, and the chaces are that if you enjoyed Portal, then you will also enjoy Antichamber. To every puzzle you encounter there is a hint provided. Hints are philosophical reflections, which also give solutions to puzzles - but they are not straightforward and require some logical thinking (you may figure out every puzzle the first time without trial & error style of play - which was the case in Portal too many a time - but as the puzzles become more and more complex you will finally encounter ones that are too difficult for that, unless you are smarter than the developer or me at least). Fortunately, the philosophical reflections are not of 2deep4u kind, so you are not constantly molested with ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ stuff. They are very simple and kind of cute. It's like the guy who made this game wasn't a typical recluse indie developer suffering from affective disorders and egocentrism, but actually a reasonable and smart dude. The gameworld consist of multiple corridors, which branch in many ways and it's the player who chooses which way he prefers to go (or rather - how he solves puzzles, because they often have multiple solutions). At any time you may come back to any previously encountered puzzle and solve it again, perhaps in a different way leading you to another branch of the "chamber". Overall, I enjoy this game a lot, despite my inner prejudice towards puzzle and adventure games.

Y todo ello creado por una sola persona. Fantástico.

content:
Posted: February 15
												Antichamber is a rather unique puzzle game, where you go around a maze like area, exploring vague life lessons, and getting your mind blown by impossible objects and geometry. There's not much in ways of story, as the main theme is to complete a wide variety of puzzles in order to reach the end, but the game is fun regardless.Gameplay and Visual wise: Everything about this game fits the tone of one word: unique. The game looks unique to say the least, as well as simplistic. If you're not a fan of bright colors, or bright colors hurt your head, you may want to tone down the brightness just a bit when playing through 85% of the game. The puzzles are quite unique, with some puzzles being rather challenging, while others can be easily accomplished with late game items (or item rather). There really was never a time I felt absolutely stumped on a puzzle, as the mechanics and the "cube ray" are demonstrated in a straightforward manner to the player. Story and Completion wise: Really there is not much to say for either of these. There isn't much of a story in the game, other than life lessons that can be seen as collectibles, and completing the game is as simple as getting to the end and finding every life lesson. There are the purple blocks, yes, however you may easily find most of the blocks when exploring the various rooms. Keep a look out in every room you come across, and completing the game is easy.Recommendation: For a puzzle game, this game does stand out with rather unique mechanics and looks, with life lessons being shown to the player along the way. If you want to have a relaxing time, solving puzzles and exploring, I would highly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2013
												Antichamber has blossomed from an Unreal Tournament 2004 project into a deceptively minimalistic puzzle game. It is an excellent addition to any gaming library thanks to its challenging puzzles and its psychological manipulation of common expectations. While the basic cell-shaded graphics may be down to the game's budget, Antichamber pulls them off brilliantly. Bright primary colours blanket areas where other games might use high quality textures, and interesting particle effects stand out as a visual cue rather than as something to be expected. This adds to the game's poignant art style, as well as making it run smoothly on less capable computers.Antichamber's gameplay mechanics switch between bending the fabric of reality and rule-oriented cube placement. Many puzzles' currencies are doled out as these collectable cubes, with different colours representing possible hints towards a solution. Other puzzles involving movement, physics, and even view orientation are welcome additions that are interspersed regularly. The pacing flows nicely between areas, and each puzzle is unique enough to stay fresh. Rooms that seem inaccessible earlier on will eventually be attainable once new techniques of manipulating cubes are discovered. While this does make for a lot of back-tracking, Antichamber's theme revolves around revisiting the impossible.Aside from teaching the basics of how to utilize its tools, the game leaves interaction with its cubed building-blocks up to the player. The imposed experiential learning leads to many “Eureka!” moments during Antichamber's journey. The game balances them perfectly with some of the more difficult challenges; each solution is just enough of an ego boost to keep spirits high before perplexing players with a new situation. Even the more stupefying tasks never seem arduous, in part because of their basic elegance but also thanks to the omnipresent musical atmosphere.Excellent sound effects are probably the main reason why Antichamber maintains such a calm ambiance. Whether splashing through a shallow pond or standing on a windy mountaintop, the sounds of nature are always present and never get tedious. This contrast between the game's claustrophobic interiors and its superb outdoor soundscape is very mentally stimulating and adds to Antichamber's aloofness. Thankfully, the oddly juxtaposed soundtrack avoids over-complicating itself, which keeps the focus on exploring and solving puzzles.Depending on how thoroughly it's completed, expect this journey to last between eight to twelve hours. Although certain puzzles are inevitably stumping, pulling through them is what makes Antichamber so satisfying to play. Its engrossing atmosphere and frequent instances of disbelief combine to form one of this generation's most appealing puzzle games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												Duck. Did I say duck ? Yeah, because that's what the game feels like. Wibbly wobbly duckin' duck. Whoever enters this place, leave here all your preconceived ideas about what games are, along with your definition of logic. Might as well put your sanity in a box and kick it goodbye until you finish Antichamber.  That's what I did after 10 minutes, and it felt great. For the 5 hours it lasted, I enjoyed being toyed around by an unending flow of pseudo-philosophical panels, a weird mix of portal-like puzzles and weird thingies, made of cubes, eyes and colors. I came sceptical, I shouldn't have. I came thinking forward is forward, that up is up, and that I was smart. Turns out I was wrong. So, what is Antichamber ? Definitely not a game that'll make you laugh. Definitely not a game that'll make you feel accomplished. Hell, I don't even know if I can call it a game. But if you are willing to take a probe up your try something new, something that will challenge everything you know, then go forward. You won't understand everything. You won't like everything. You probably won't play more than 30mn at a time. But this is probably one of the only game I've ever played that I will remember, not because of it's gameplay, but because of it's meaning and contents. What are you waiting for ?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2013
												Antichamber is probably my favorite puzzle game of all time. The puzzles themselves are not what makes this game unique, but the line being constantly crossed between what's real and unreal. The game isn't "oh so crazy" that trying to navigate logically will screw you over, but it also does not obey the rules of space. I wanted to keep playing, to the end, without stopping, and I do believe that would be the best way to do it for the experience. The ambient track is slightly unsettling/calming, and the whole concept and execution has loads of meaning which is up for you to find yourself. I do believe this was very well done, except I do think it could've done without the signs everywhere with cliché life lessons for hints. That's my one gripe, but other than that, this game seems to have accomplished its goal and is truly complete and something to consider.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
												Calling 'Antichamber' a game either says too much or says too little. Yes, you can succeed in 'Antichamber,' sometimes on accident; there are puzzles to solve, and there is a goal. But the goal doesn't really matter; 'Antichamber' is definitely about the things you see on the journey rather than the destination or even the journey itself. The puzzles should be maddening, but they're not. There is a soothing, peaceful detachment to the game, as you wander around the impossible, intricate maze. The mechanic of the space around you warping based on your perception doesn't get old, though there are times when you just really, really want to get past a door - and have absolutely no idea how to do so.It's definitely not for everyone, but it's worth a look for no other reason than just to see it. Clever, strange, and created by accident (the origin of 'Antichamber' was a mistake by its creator while building an entirely different sort of game).

So, kudos to the developer for making one hell of an experience.Well worth it in my opinion.“We can appreciate the entire journey by looking back at how far we have come.” -AC

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												antichamber is one of the best puzzle games ive ever played, this game constantly blows your mind away and its one of the very very few games id call "artistic" such as Braid, Ico and Shadow of the Colossusi consider this game should be played knowing as little about it as you can, that being said i suggest you read no futher since im going into detail of what makes this game great and its main faultI CONSIDER THE FOLLOWING SPOILERS, ID AVOID READING IF I WAS YOU:one of the most impressive things about the game is how it can be similar to portal and completely different from portal, both are puzzle games in first person where you use a "gun" to solve the different puzzles in the environment, also both use a lot of white hehe. however once you dig depper into antichamber, you realize its actually the complete opposite of Portal, Portal makes you feel like you are part of something big, it also makes you feel like theres a world out there, an entire universe beyond aperture labs walls, antichamber does not do this, for all we know those halls you tread in antichamber might be all there is in the universe. Portal makes huge emphasis on science and logic, everything about it makes reference to this often in a very humorous way, the world of antichamber is governed by non-sequiturs and absurdity, it is a non-euclidean plane in which running in a straight line can make you end up going in circles, you can fall 50 meters off a cliff down a hole, turn around and find yourself at the top of the cliff again, among other mind bending things. if the world of antichamber abides to any sort of laws they are fundamentally different to the ones our universe abidesmost puzzles in the game are solved with the aid a "gun" that allows you to take and place cubes in different places, you can activate laser tripwires with those cubes, use it to create platforms to stand up, etc. as you progress through the game, your gun acquires new functionsusually i consider a game art when the setting and gameplay of the game combine to tell a story with almost no exposition, or is used to push ideas into the mind of the player by the use of gameplay alone, antichamber is one of those games, everything in the game pushes the idea of a world of complete nonsense or governed by laws completely different to the ones we have come to expect, both from our universe and games in general, ive already explained how the game takes place in an non-euclidean plane, but theres also the fact the game is a non-linear succession of puzzles, you will very often solve puzzles only to find yourself in previous rooms, and yet the game very subtlety lets you know youve made progress, such as by taking you back to a puzzle you could previously not solve because your gun wasnt upgraded yet, or something like that, you will only reach the conclusion of most puzzles if you let this unorthodox place get into you and you start developing unorthodox solutions to the puzzles. most puzzles games work like this: the game puts you in front of a table places a jigsaw puzzle on that table and asks you to solve it, antichamber puts you in front of a table places a jigsaw puzzle on that table, takes a few pieces and hides em somewhere in the room without telling you and then asks you to solve the puzzle, you MUST think outside the box, but the game always finds a way to subtely hint at the solution, hell im sure a couple of times youll find a solution by accident just by going "meh ♥♥♥♥ it" and doing something that in normal circunstances would be a futile exercise, such as jumping agaisnt a wall you cant reach or something like thatthe downside to this puzzle design is that it commits one of the biggest capital sins of puzzle games, some solutions take too long to implement, you see, most good puzzle games make sure that you take a good time coming up with a solution for the puzzle, yet they make the process of implementing this solution fast, this is why portal is so great, after youve come up with the solution the actual process of implementing it is fast and usually involves exhilaratingly flying through the air. this is where antichamber falls short, many solutions take a long time to implement and might even leave you questioning yourself if you are doing things rightthe sounds and aesthetics of the game are nice, the latter deserve special credit for being unique and striking, using little detail and a significant amount of color, however is a bit too bright sometimesit took me 8 hours to finish the game and i havent completed it 100% (tough im very close) so it has a good length for a puzzle gamei very strongly recommend this gameUPDATE: completed the game 100%, took me 8.7 hours, as i said, good length for a puzzle game

content:
Posted: February 25, 2013
												Easily one of the best puzzle games ever created. This game pulls off the trick of creating a 3d environment out of an Escher drawing. The game takes place entirely in what is like a maze of puzzles and all the while twisting back on itself and bending the rules of reality to both mind boggling as well as enchanting levels. The puzzles do get challenging and while there is no real story, the cryptic messages found on the walls throughout the game sort of give the sense that you are being watched, not by some character but rather by the antichamber itself. It is a beautiful concept of creating a sort of relationship with the environment and unlocking its secrets and learning that there really are some rules, is an incredibly rewading experience. Do yourself a service as well as partake in the pleasure of playing this hallmark of game design.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												A mind-twisting experience that will force you to constantly think outside the box. Only the box is 4 dimentional. Or is it? Antichamber throws all conventional puzzling out the window, and constantly forces you to improvise, observe, and think. Sometimes the solution can be as simple as 'look in a specific direction'. Because in Antichamber, rules of physics do not apply. Or they do, and you just do not understand how. The experience is the definition of non-linearity and is pretty much one of a kind. If you like to challenge your mind and are not repulsed by somewhat unpleasant art-style, if you'd like to expirience something unique, get Antichamber. And remember - the sings may help you more than you think.

												Cool puzzle game, with nice aesthetics. The high difficulty, and the secrets to be found would give you upwards of 8 hours of playability, which may be a bit short for the price, depending on your budget. However, the aesthetics and soundtrack were big pluses, immersing you in the game, despite there being no narrative.If you're into puzzle games for their own sake, I'd definitely reccommend. content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												I think my favorite part about this game is how it interacts with you; how it teaches you subliminally the rules of the world. It is a very fresh experience that promotes self-investigation. The closest thing to the game telling you its actual rules are these parables you come across. Antichamber does not play out in strict Euclidean space, and the laws of physics are not expressed the same as we experience them in real life. This produces a world with its own flavor and intrinsic beauty. Learning the way the world works in Antichamber IS the driving force of its gameplay, and WOW is it done well.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												Reality-bending first person puzzler. On first play, I thought it was interesting and clever but also very frustrating. Second time I played, I found the first manipulation device and it all started to click. The puzzles are often hard but always logical within the rules that antichamber lays out (so far at least).The introduction of new concepts is well paced. The only thing I'm not sure I like is the fact that you'll encounter plenty of puzzles that cannot be solved until you revist them later with a new manipulation tool. There are positives to that approach but I also think it leads to a lot of confusion and frustration that could easilly put someone off.Overall, I highly recommend this. Just make sure you're willing to stick at it for a while and you'll find a great puzzle game with some very satisfying moments.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												Antichamber, a game which hardly makes sense, except that sense is not required here, because all you have to really use is your brain, making your way through your "life".Basically this game is to teach some meanings of life, in a fun way, you have to make through various puzzles using tips used in real life, like for example: If you only think of right now, you won't have enough for later. Things that you mother and father would tell you during the course of your life.I can say that this game is not really supposed to have a story, I could say that this is mostly a game to think to solve the puzzles, and maybe learn something which is going to be REALLY useful in your life, in a fun way, until you are able to finish your "quest" or as it can be seen in this game, your "life".Graphics: I'll say that the graphic is quite simple, but yet very attractive and colorful (I love colorful games!) in some parts, and the block gun look very interesting and ironically, reverses the conditions colors I like to use specially in survival games (Blue for perfect health, Green for little damage, yellow for medium damage and red for heavy damage), being the first on the blue and the last the Red gun, as a little downside, I think most of the corridors were a little lifeless, the walls were all white, it gives you a strange feeling of lolyness, maybe it was the intention of the game (9.5/10)Story: Like mentioned before, I believe this game wasn't really made to have a story, except for learning some meanings of life in a fun way, and the player (which the appearance is unknown) must pass the challenges in his "life", none of the happenings made any sense at all, like, why (s)he was there, who was (s)he, and what happened in the ending (I'll avoid making spoilers). The story didn't make much sense, so I'm afraid the story will get a so so rating, but hey! Just because the story is confusing somewhat doesn't mean the game is bad! (6/10)Sound: Whoa, how I did like the sounds in the game, the sounds gave quite a good touch to the game, when you are falling at a very high speed, that good sound of the air passing on your ears, when you land, and the sounds of you moving, absorbing and firing the blocks, gave a great touch to the game, in any moment I never got tired of the sound effects, and the music was very calm, a perfect music to let the player think through the puzzles, I simply have nothing but good things to say about the sounds (10/10)Depth: Depending on how well can you think on the solution of the puzzles, the game can take quite a while to beat (I almost beat the game 100% in around 20 hours, being some of those hours idle), and having various different paths, including some deadends, if you are looking to explore everything in the game, it's going to take a while, if you are just aiming to find the exit, the game will be a bit shorter, looking at the map (there is a map of the rooms explored on the wall of the game start chamber), the game seems to have needed to have a few more rooms. (8/10)Addictiveness: Awesome, I can safely say that until I could find almost all the black signs (you can see all the black signs you found during the game on the game start chamber), I never got tired of the game, but after I've given up to find the last 5 black signs, I didn't really feel like playing again. (8/10)Difficulty: I can say that the difficulty is at it's exact point to the human mind, the challenges fits exactly accordingly to a smart person, I had to put a lot of thought through the challenges, to solve 'em, some were simple, and some you had to be more experienced and have more "Tools" to work them out. (7/10 = Tough)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												I don't think I've fallen in love with a game more instantaneously than I have with Antichamber. While I'm far from considering myself a "classic gamer", one thing I find a bit exasperating about almost all modern games is how they will persistently hold your hand in a manner that, even if it doesn’t remove the challenge entirely, certainly does a lot to insult your intelligence. You will not run into this problem in Antichamber, and this for me is its main charm. Much like the very first Legend of Zelda game, AC starts you out in an unknown, unexplained world and you have to learn the rules by yourself, some writing on the walls telling you how to control your newfound matter gun (which I didn't even find until maybe 2 hours in playing the game and honestly completely forgot about until I did) and upgrades the only real guides you'll be getting, aside from some delightful life lessons you only receive after completing the puzzles they refer to. The simple puzzles quickly become daunting and brain-teasing, though a small few can become a bit tedious (and one puzzle in particular, albeit optional and only leading to an extra dev room, is complete and utter BS). However, for the most part the game has an excellent track record of keeping your mind stimulated and providing many rewarding and even cathartic moments, and many puzzles are an absolute joy for me to replay over and over again.I also love the game’s minimalist presentation. You’ll be spending a lot of your time in pure white hallways, frequently visiting rooms that sport a color scheme ripped out of an MS Paint palette, but the game finds ways to use even its graphic simplicity to its advantage (many of the game’s puzzles and tricks wouldn’t work too well, I don’t think, in a more detailed aesthetic). I’ve seen people refer to the game as “ugly”, and while it certainly isn’t too easy on the eyes, it still finds ways to look just as charming as it plays.At a glance, the game could easily be describled as "Portal with blocks” (even though development on this game started a year before Portal was released), but what sets it apart from its mad scientist peer more than anything is while Portal follows a very linear storyline, AC is completely open, nonlinear, and ready and waiting to have every conceivable corner explored—as soon as you figure out your way around. Another important difference that makes AC stand on its own is that where Portal’s theme is based around physics, science and strict logic, AC’s theme is its complete and utter deconstruction of your preconceptions of logic and reality, and while logic isn’t necessarily completely absent from the game, it has created its own, new set of rules that, again, you have to figure out for yourself.This game did have me stumped on more than a few occasions and I will admit have committed the sin of using a walkthrough to help me through a few of them (although all but one of them ended up being dev rooms), but after seeing the answers its clear that a player’s inability to proceed really does simply stem from their lack of ability to put pieces together rather than a negligence of giving you all the tools you need and teaching you how to use them—there are plenty of subtle, clever lessons leading up to larger problems, but it’s up to you to actually learn them and keep them in your head.Overall, I’d say my only big complaint with Antichamber is that there isn’t more of it. There’s no real extra content aside from the hidden dev rooms, and apart from restarting your save file to finish with a faster time there isn’t exactly much in the way of replay value, and asking for a sequel to a game like this in my opinion would be outrageous. Still, if Bruce does come up with something, I’d love to see it and will be the first in line to get it. :) This game is without a doubt one of the finest I’ve played and is an absolute must-have for puzzle game enthusiasts.

Posted: June 13, 2014
												Antichamber is a first person puzzle game set in non-euclidean space. Each area has its own internal logic, but some of the mechanics of the various guns which you get can take a little bit to figure out - this game can be VERY hard at times. It's difficult to describe in greater detail without spiling some aspects of the puzzles itself, so I would simply recommend that you check it out if you like difficult puzzle games and/or things which break the logic of reality as you're used to it.I will note that the saturated colors of the graphic style can take some getting used to, but it ends up being rather charming.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												On the surface, this game doesn't have much to boast: it's mostly in black and white, and the graphics are far from optimized, which can actually cause motion sickness. However, once you get into the game you're in for hours of entertainment and mind-bending puzzles. You'll encounter situations that would otherwise occur only in an M. C. Escher painting, and the first casualty of the game will be your basic sense of geometric logic. Your mind will twist in a way that puts even Portal to shame, that you can't help but wonder in amazement how the developers even got the engine to behave like they wanted it to. And when you do finally end up solving the puzzles, the sense of accomplishment you get from it is like almost nothing else.If you don't have this game in your Steam Library, you should fix that problem ASAP, because this game really is that fun. It has an extremely simple control scheme, but the game is so complex and deep that it definitely beats many other titles out there.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												This is one of the toughest thumbs-up decisions I've made.  I bought this game because it looked interesting and different, and had some good reviews.  And it IS interesting.  The word "different," however, does not fully convey the magnitude of its strangeness.This is a game with which I have a love/hate relationship.  I love the concept -- a game that subverts physical rules and creates its own completely bizarre and disorienting (albeit very very minimalist) world.  I love the break from conventional big-name first-person games that do nothing but show you pretty scenery in which you run around and kill people.  And I initially loved the challenge of solving these weird, brain-teasing puzzles.That is, until I started to hate it.  I hate the fact that the gameworld very very frequently loops back on itself and you find yourself solving the same puzzles that you went through quite a while ago.  Perhaps there is a way to play this game so that you avoid all of these loop-back pitfalls; I don't know.  But all too often, I'd fall through a hole that suddenly materializes, or I'd turn a corner, and I'm back at a place that I had passed a long time ago.  This is enough to make me turn off the game in utter frustration.I also hate the save-game mechanics, which are completely checkpoint-based and not controllable by the player, and do NOT let you save  wherever you want to save.  The checkpoints are too far apart, for one thing.  For another, because of the way that the game loops back on itself, and the fact that the gameworld is so completely disorienting anyway, these checkpoints are rendered fairly useless.  So I'm back at this weird eye in the wall.  For the 29th time.  Except something might be a bit different about it this time around.  You see the problem here?This game is like a practical joke on the player.  Still, after these long periods of utter frustration and downtime (quitting the game in disgust), after a few days or a week there is a strange compulsion to give it another go.  To see if any progress can be made THIS TIME.  It's masochistic in a way.  The fascinating, mindbending puzzles keep calling me back, my frustration with the game notwithstanding. I have not finished this game yet, not sure if I'll even be compelled to make it that far.  We'll see.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												Extremely fun puzzle game, with a very different take on the genre. I enetered this game expecting it to be akin to Portal, and while it was in some senses, they are two entirely different experiences. Portal gets you to think with...portals, and Antichamber just simply requires you to think outside the box. While it is a simple concept, some of the challenges can prove to be quite difficult.I really cant find many problems with this game. The only thing that comes to mind is that sometimes the  game can  double up on the solution to puzzles. This is quite noticable around midway through the game, when around 2-3 of the puzzles have the same solution. That being said, the sheer uniqueness of some of the other puzzles more than make up for this. Some may find that the game isn't extremely replayable. However, for me this wasn't too much of a problem, and I thoroughly enjoyed the game even on my second playthrough. Overall, amazing game, an extremely unique game to the genre, and a must-buy during sales.9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												Duck. Did I say duck ? Yeah, because that's what the game feels like. Wibbly wobbly duckin' duck. Whoever enters this place, leave here all your preconceived ideas about what games are, along with your definition of logic. Might as well put your sanity in a box and kick it goodbye until you finish Antichamber.  That's what I did after 10 minutes, and it felt great. For the 5 hours it lasted, I enjoyed being toyed around by an unending flow of pseudo-philosophical panels, a weird mix of portal-like puzzles and weird thingies, made of cubes, eyes and colors. I came sceptical, I shouldn't have. I came thinking forward is forward, that up is up, and that I was smart. Turns out I was wrong. So, what is Antichamber ? Definitely not a game that'll make you laugh. Definitely not a game that'll make you feel accomplished. Hell, I don't even know if I can call it a game. But if you are willing to take a probe up your try something new, something that will challenge everything you know, then go forward. You won't understand everything. You won't like everything. You probably won't play more than 30mn at a time. But this is probably one of the only game I've ever played that I will remember, not because of it's gameplay, but because of it's meaning and contents. What are you waiting for ?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2013
												It's a first person puzzler that screws with your head. Unlike Portal, which gave you brain-bending ways to explore the physics of the real world (flinging, wheeeeeee!), Antichamber dispenses with the real world altogether. Turn around and you may not see the room you just came from. Turn a corner and find yourself where you were. Rooms overlap, you can go up by going sideways, and things disappear when you stop looking...All of this sounds like it doesn't make sense, but very pleasingly it does. The place runs on logic and self-consistency and everything (well, I suspect most things) has a well-reasoned solution. The puzzles are solid, polished, and nothing's so hard that you can't solve it. The game took me about 8 hours to beat (across three nights), and I liked all of it.Play this game and feel your mind being turned inside-out.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												I give Anti-Chamber a 9/10.  I really like this gameGraphics: BEAUTIFUL!  Yet they are really not demanding at all, I can even run this on my work computers Intel HD 3000.  They are simple but the colors and patterns are just incredibleStability: Game play is smooth.  It runs on the Unreal 3 engine so everything works wellGame play:  Everything is totally original.  You will see so many game making innovations from the menu which is literally in first person mode to the crazy colors that make you feel like you are in space odyssey 2001.  Its kind of like a psychedelic Portal.  The little mementos on the walls are really clever and I wish I could put them up on the walls in my home.Issues:  I'm not very good at solving puzzles and I really have not been able to finish the game.  This is disappointing to me.  When I finally get around to revisiting antichamber I have typically forgotten how to go about the game and its basically like restarting.  If there was some sort of hint system for us dummies, I might like it 10/10.

												Cool puzzle game, with nice aesthetics. I was hoping for more surreal spacial awareness based puzzles, but about an hour in most of the puzzles become resource management type, involving the block firing gun, This was still really fun, and also really surreal in it's own way (which was exemplified by the the lack of handholding), but not really what I was expecting. The game was challenging, but usually with branching paths, so you're seldom completely stuck (though it does happen). The high difficulty, and the secrets to be found would give you upwards of 8 hours of playability, which may be a bit short for the price, depending on your budget. However, the aesthetics and soundtrack were big pluses, immersing you in the game, despite there being no narrative.If you're into puzzle games for their own sake, I'd definitely reccommend. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												No doubt, Antichamber is a hard game. It's not so much that it challenges the skill of a player, his reaction times, his ability to multi-task or, as you might think from the screenshots with the gun, his precision with a crosshair. Antichamber throws the player into a labyrinth of wisdom for life, one that will sometimes force you to take a step back and see the greater scheme of things, one that will throw you back for you to start over again and make you learn from unforeseeable mistakes. It's what makes this game immersive. You don't know what to expect, what you'll encounter around the next corner or even better, what you will encounter after an endless set of corners. What is the sense of this? There might be no answer to that question. This is Antichamber, a metaphor for life.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												antichamber is one of the best puzzle games ive ever played, this game constantly blows your mind away and its one of the very very few games id call "artistic" such as Braid, Ico and Shadow of the Colossusi consider this game should be played knowing as little about it as you can, that being said i suggest you read no futher since im going into detail of what makes this game great and its main faultI CONSIDER THE FOLLOWING SPOILERS, ID AVOID READING IF I WAS YOU:one of the most impressive things about the game is how it can be similar to portal and completely different from portal, both are puzzle games in first person where you use a "gun" to solve the different puzzles in the environment, also both use a lot of white hehe. however once you dig depper into antichamber, you realize its actually the complete opposite of Portal, Portal makes you feel like you are part of something big, it also makes you feel like theres a world out there, an entire universe beyond aperture labs walls, antichamber does not do this, for all we know those halls you tread in antichamber might be all there is in the universe. Portal makes huge emphasis on science and logic, everything about it makes reference to this often in a very humorous way, the world of antichamber is governed by non-sequiturs and absurdity, it is a non-euclidean plane in which running in a straight line can make you end up going in circles, you can fall 50 meters off a cliff down a hole, turn around and find yourself at the top of the cliff again, among other mind bending things. if the world of antichamber abides to any sort of laws they are fundamentally different to the ones our universe abidesmost puzzles in the game are solved with the aid a "gun" that allows you to take and place cubes in different places, you can activate laser tripwires with those cubes, use it to create platforms to stand up, etc. as you progress through the game, your gun acquires new functionsusually i consider a game art when the setting and gameplay of the game combine to tell a story with almost no exposition, or is used to push ideas into the mind of the player by the use of gameplay alone, antichamber is one of those games, everything in the game pushes the idea of a world of complete nonsense or governed by laws completely different to the ones we have come to expect, both from our universe and games in general, ive already explained how the game takes place in an non-euclidean plane, but theres also the fact the game is a non-linear succession of puzzles, you will very often solve puzzles only to find yourself in previous rooms, and yet the game very subtlety lets you know youve made progress, such as by taking you back to a puzzle you could previously not solve because your gun wasnt upgraded yet, or something like that, you will only reach the conclusion of most puzzles if you let this unorthodox place get into you and you start developing unorthodox solutions to the puzzles. most puzzles games work like this: the game puts you in front of a table places a jigsaw puzzle on that table and asks you to solve it, antichamber puts you in front of a table places a jigsaw puzzle on that table, takes a few pieces and hides em somewhere in the room without telling you and then asks you to solve the puzzle, you MUST think outside the box, but the game always finds a way to subtely hint at the solution, hell im sure a couple of times youll find a solution by accident just by going "meh ♥♥♥♥ it" and doing something that in normal circunstances would be a futile exercise, such as jumping agaisnt a wall you cant reach or something like thatthe downside to this puzzle design is that it commits one of the biggest capital sins of puzzle games, some solutions take too long to implement, you see, most good puzzle games make sure that you take a good time coming up with a solution for the puzzle, yet they make the process of implementing this solution fast, this is why portal is so great, after youve come up with the solution the actual process of implementing it is fast and usually involves exhilaratingly flying through the air. this is where antichamber falls short, many solutions take a long time to implement and might even leave you questioning yourself if you are doing things rightthe sounds and aesthetics of the game are nice, the latter deserve special credit for being unique and striking, using little detail and a significant amount of color, however is a bit too bright sometimesit took me 8 hours to finish the game and i havent completed it 100% (tough im very close) so it has a good length for a puzzle gamei very strongly recommend this gameUPDATE: completed the game 100%, took me 8.7 hours, as i said, good length for a puzzle game

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												This game is first person adventure game in which you manuever around a series of chambers tryingto get to "The End," which always seems so close yet so far.  The game beings with chambers/rooms that are more mind-bending and riddle-based, relying on manipulation of your senes, namely what you see and your sense of direction.  Sometimes you'll hear sounds which can serve as clues.  There is no dialogue in the game except for the brief life lessons attached to small images scattered before and after many of the rooms and puzzles.  Some have found these to be a little patronizing, but I found them to very charming and they provided a narrative to an otherwise silent and minimalist game.  These bits of wisdom and the ability to appreciate them I think is crucial in the enjoyment of Antechamber as a game.  This collection of images and messages are added to the "antichamber" which acts as your base throughout the game and to where you can escape to at any point by clicking ESC.   This room gives you access to somewhat cryptic map of where you have traveled so far and allows you to quick travel to the puzzles so you do not have to waste time finding them again in the brain boggling realm.  The game quickly (or not so quickly, depending on your pacing), moves from a game that relies on manipulating your perceptions to a game that relies on more understandable puzzles (not necessarily easy to solve, but easier to see what your objective is).  This transformation happens when you find a gun that allows you to manipulate cubes in the world around you that you use to solve puzzles.  Of course, puzzles still test the limits of your imagination and your ability to think outside the box   These puzzles till test your ability to see things in different ways and give you more easily discernable objectives in which you have to cultivate novel ways to get to.  The game is still non-linear and puzzles can be solved in different ways or bypassed completely by taking another path.  Some have found the game frustrating in that it seems intent on forcing impractical and unthinkable solutions on the player, but the game is ultimately about learning.  In this mini-universe, you have to learn and find new skills, which is what many of the messages try to convey.  For this reason, I want to describe this as a sandbox game, not in that you can change the rules of the game as you see fit, but that you are in this sandbox, and you are given a certain set of tools and rules, and with those tools and rules you can do anything you want in trying to navigate your way through the dungeon crawl.  The game is definitely a learning experience and a lesson in keeping you rmind open to new ideas.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
												I cannot stress this enough, do not look online for tutorials, don't let someone else guide you through this game. As easy as it would be to have a complete stranger guide you through your life and tell you what is correct and what is not, you don't let them because life is about making mistakes and finding solutions. This game parallels that in so many regards. It guides you through a story that only you can narrate, it helps you learn and gives you direction, but not once does it allow you to take advantage an glide right through. The game offers constant challenges and forces the questioning of what you are doing. The solution rarely is clear until you have found it, and there's no fun in allowing someone else to find it for you.AntiChamber is a downright fascinating game and a beautiful strain on the mind, I urge anyone with the patience to pick up this game and let it take you on a strange and perplexing journey

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Antichamber is a mind-bending puzzler. The closest I can get is "it's like Portal but while tripping on at least 3 different drugs." It defies description. Don't spoil it for yourself, don't watch Let's Plays, don't ask for help, just get it and go. Beat it in one sitting if you can; it's better that way, and assuming you don't go for 100% completion (if there even is such a thing) then it only takes about 4 hours.While some parts of the game can be a pain and some parts will cause headaches, there are only a few puzzles that you *MUST* complete to progress through the game. That said, the more you skip, the harder the remaining puzzles will be.The first time I played it was a spiritual experience. I enjoyed watching some friends struggle through the asinine challenges and watched their minds repeatedly blown. It's a brilliant exercise in thinking so far outside of the box that you escape the bounds of reality and end up back inside the box.And here's a hint: Pay very careful attention. Move slowly and take your time - you'll spot the solutions much more quickly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2013
												If Portal's sense of humor was directed at its environment instead of its narrative.If Obsidian's developers turned their minds towards puzzles instead of point-and-click.Your steps bend space, space bends time, time bends you. The walls expand and contract and rearrange. Your memory is irrelevant, your skills and powers of logic are tested. Your ability to learn from your mistakes is emphasized. Consistency was left behind ages ago.Take the Manipulator. Take the boxes. Find the right way down through the maze, to the food, then find the exit.  Push the exit button.   If the food tastes awful, don't eat it, go back and try another way.They want the same thing that you do, really, they want a path, just like you.  You are in a maze in a maze, but which one counts?  Your maze, their maze, my maze.  Or are the mazes all the same, defined by the limits of their paths?Existence is simple: find the food, push the button, hit the treadmill.But sometimes it gets much harder.  Sometimes the food makes you sick, or you can hear nearby feet racing you, urging you on.  Sometimes the button only gets you landed right back in the beginning of the maze again, and the food won't satisfy.There is only one path and that is the path that you take, but you can take more than one path.Cross over the cell bars, find a new maze, make the maze from it's path, find the cell bars, cross over the bars, find a maze, make the maze from its path, eat the food, eat the path.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
CAUTION: MAJOR HEAD TRIP AHEAD!Be prepared to have your brain hurt as this game defies most standard logic about the world!Antichamber is a puzzle platformer that can stand with the likes of the Portal series.  While the 3D graphics are minimalistic,  the challenges that are presented will force you to rethink HOW you approach the problem.  There's no enemies or creatures to defeat, only puzzles with a special block gun (& upgrades) that you'll find as you explore from room to room as you eventually find your way out of the space known as "The Antichamber".Armed with only the basic controls & a target timer (which is something you can COMPLETELY IGNORE, as taking longer than what the game notes is perfectly OK... it's just a challenge that you can partake in), you explore the various rooms & the unique challenges they can present.  The game has a very surreal feel as it takes advantages of things that cannot be done in reality (like endless coridors & instant teleportation through forced perspectives).While the game DOES NOT have any save support, it DOES offer shortcuts to players who are perceptive to find them... as well as secrets for those who wish to uncover every secret The Antichamber has to offer.If you love the Portal series, you'll definitely enjoy Antichamber as well!

content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												I give Anti-Chamber a 9/10.  I really like this gameGraphics: BEAUTIFUL!  Yet they are really not demanding at all, I can even run this on my work computers Intel HD 3000.  They are simple but the colors and patterns are just incredibleStability: Game play is smooth.  It runs on the Unreal 3 engine so everything works wellGame play:  Everything is totally original.  You will see so many game making innovations from the menu which is literally in first person mode to the crazy colors that make you feel like you are in space odyssey 2001.  Its kind of like a psychedelic Portal.  The little mementos on the walls are really clever and I wish I could put them up on the walls in my home.Issues:  I'm not very good at solving puzzles and I really have not been able to finish the game.  This is disappointing to me.  When I finally get around to revisiting antichamber I have typically forgotten how to go about the game and its basically like restarting.  If there was some sort of hint system for us dummies, I might like it 10/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												This game will REALLY mess with your head, as it does not obey the basic principles of 3D space: you can have halways that wrap around themselves or rooms that exist in the same cartesian coortinades as another room you visited. So you end up tracing "paths" more than physical location. Even how you look at the walls, and what direction you face while you walk, determine what will happen in many cases. The game's simple mechanics are used and usable in very clever ways that will keep you scratching your head for a while. Even if you cheat a little with a guide you will have fun just seeing this wonderful creation unfold for yourself - even if you rob yourself of one or two "aha!" moments. If you can avoid it though, do :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2013
												Antichamber is a very cognitive experience, an almost perfect example of the thoughtful puzzler, abstracted away from even a framing narrative.  It's a novelty that I exulted in, one of the most beautiful states of mind that I've recently had the chance to enjoy.  You play this game by leaving all external cues behind, and you learn to move through the not-a-world by applying internally consistent rules.  Yet, for all that abstraction, it offers graceful pointers, where the lessons learned are themselves collectibles.  It is a game about the game, which is not like other games...  I love it so much;  11 hours and an absolute joy to return to.  This.... this is what finely crafted thought looks like, when it is turned into a shared world for others: Abstract Art  that I can really walk through.  It creates a monument of inquisitive perception in the mind of the player.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												Extremely fun puzzle game, with a very different take on the genre. I enetered this game expecting it to be akin to Portal, and while it was in some senses, they are two entirely different experiences. Portal gets you to think with...portals, and Antichamber just simply requires you to think outside the box. While it is a simple concept, some of the challenges can prove to be quite difficult.I really cant find many problems with this game. The only thing that comes to mind is that sometimes the  game can  double up on the solution to puzzles. This is quite noticable around midway through the game, when around 2-3 of the puzzles have the same solution. That being said, the sheer uniqueness of some of the other puzzles more than make up for this. Some may find that the game isn't extremely replayable. However, for me this wasn't too much of a problem, and I thoroughly enjoyed the game even on my second playthrough. Overall, amazing game, an extremely unique game to the genre, and a must-buy during sales.9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												Antichamber is a first-person puzzle game. It's not like anything like you've seen before. Looking at the game screenshots you can clearly see that its graphics are awesome. But if you will buy this game, you will experience something more than just brilliant game. Throughout the game the very matter of your mind will change and you will look at things around you differrently. Every room you will encounter will require you to forget all you have learnt throughout your real life. The game itself will crush your common sense just as you will notice that there are no such thing as x, y and z axis. walking through the door can lead you to the room that was above you seconds ago. Besides messing with your brain with mind-twisting puzzles Antichamber guides you through your life with signs you can read after completing each challenge. (Shhh! Antichamber is also full of easter eggs!)  Antichamber is a clearly philosophical game as it doesn't have a plot. (Yes, that's right. You just spawn in the dark room and follow instructions how to enter the Antichamber.) The Antichamber shows the whole life cycle. For example, if at first you knew nothing about the game and the very simple element of the game puzzled you, at the end of the game even the most complex mind-breaker will not take more than five minutes to solve. Antichamber is a definite must-play.10/10

Posted: January 10, 2014
												I'll admit I went into this game expecting some type of Portal knock-off. I was very surprised by what I found.Right off the bat, huh no menu? No "click any button to begin", just in a room with a depiction of second trimester fetus....with some kind of fortune cookie caption? "Every journey is a series of choices. The first is to begin the journey."I won't spoil anything else.You will find yourself questioning things, seeing the world from a different perspective, perhaps you'll even take something valuable away from this experience. Although this might not happen in the way you expect it to...This game not only removed me from my comfort zone it made me like it. Not in a forceful way, not by punishing me, not by rewarding me, but by simply letting me play.The music is good. A somewhat ambient theme. Controls are good and simple. I like the visual style, some might not though, view some screenshots. Lastly, if you're the kind of person who plays to win, or can't just let go and immerse yourself in a game, I wouldn't recommend this for you.Everyone else, BUY THIS GAME!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2013
												The single best puzzle game since 'Portal 2'. Confusing, Intriguing, Captivating, and still Fun.  Very similar to Portal in its presentation (a basic white 'testing' environment), however - game play mechanics are a bit different.  The best description I've found is a cross between Portal and Minecraft. Each new puzzle 'room' forces you to re evaluate what is being presented versus what is possible, forcing you to constantly re-analyze your possibilities. Walkthroughs are not recommended, just patience - as leaving the game to come back with fresh eyes is the BEST way to overcome that obstacle, and reap the benefits of being proud at your own abilities. Sound FX are good and interesting, providing environmental specific background noise, but it is not intrusive. There are no themes to sing along with, no dialogue to pay attention to. In the end, the audio sets a relaxing, unobtrusive mood, and nothing more. Graphics are simple, yet refined. Due to the amount of individual 3d 'objects' you can have in the game at once - perhaps a simple graphic presentation is by design. It took a while, but with some effort, Ii WAS able to eventually crash the game by spawning enough objects to overwhelm my video abilities. Lots of enjoyment for any puzzle enthusiast. If you liked Portal, then this game is for you - and at the right price too!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												I really enjoy puzzle games, but oftentimes, they're so inspired by each other that it becomes difficult to find one that really stands out and forces you to think around problems.  That rare sort of innovation is what made Portal such a wonderful game, and the same goes for Antichamber.  It takes some time to get used to wandering around Escher-like rooms, and by the time you think you've got the mechanics figured out, the game throws entirely new challenges at you.The art style, both audio and visual, is a pleasant contrast to the challenging gameplay.  Ambient rainfall or forest sounds accompany bright, contrasting colors, helping keep you calm and focused.  Quite a nice choice for a game like this.If you enjoy games that force you to exercise your reasoning skills, Antihamber is not a game to miss.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												Antichamber, a game which hardly makes sense, except that sense is not required here, because all you have to really use is your brain, making your way through your "life".Basically this game is to teach some meanings of life, in a fun way, you have to make through various puzzles using tips used in real life, like for example: If you only think of right now, you won't have enough for later. Things that you mother and father would tell you during the course of your life.I can say that this game is not really supposed to have a story, I could say that this is mostly a game to think to solve the puzzles, and maybe learn something which is going to be REALLY useful in your life, in a fun way, until you are able to finish your "quest" or as it can be seen in this game, your "life".Graphics: I'll say that the graphic is quite simple, but yet very attractive and colorful (I love colorful games!) in some parts, and the block gun look very interesting and ironically, reverses the conditions colors I like to use specially in survival games (Blue for perfect health, Green for little damage, yellow for medium damage and red for heavy damage), being the first on the blue and the last the Red gun, as a little downside, I think most of the corridors were a little lifeless, the walls were all white, it gives you a strange feeling of lolyness, maybe it was the intention of the game (9.5/10)Story: Like mentioned before, I believe this game wasn't really made to have a story, except for learning some meanings of life in a fun way, and the player (which the appearance is unknown) must pass the challenges in his "life", none of the happenings made any sense at all, like, why (s)he was there, who was (s)he, and what happened in the ending (I'll avoid making spoilers). The story didn't make much sense, so I'm afraid the story will get a so so rating, but hey! Just because the story is confusing somewhat doesn't mean the game is bad! (6/10)Sound: Whoa, how I did like the sounds in the game, the sounds gave quite a good touch to the game, when you are falling at a very high speed, that good sound of the air passing on your ears, when you land, and the sounds of you moving, absorbing and firing the blocks, gave a great touch to the game, in any moment I never got tired of the sound effects, and the music was very calm, a perfect music to let the player think through the puzzles, I simply have nothing but good things to say about the sounds (10/10)Depth: Depending on how well can you think on the solution of the puzzles, the game can take quite a while to beat (I almost beat the game 100% in around 20 hours, being some of those hours idle), and having various different paths, including some deadends, if you are looking to explore everything in the game, it's going to take a while, if you are just aiming to find the exit, the game will be a bit shorter, looking at the map (there is a map of the rooms explored on the wall of the game start chamber), the game seems to have needed to have a few more rooms. (8/10)Addictiveness: Awesome, I can safely say that until I could find almost all the black signs (you can see all the black signs you found during the game on the game start chamber), I never got tired of the game, but after I've given up to find the last 5 black signs, I didn't really feel like playing again. (8/10)Difficulty: I can say that the difficulty is at it's exact point to the human mind, the challenges fits exactly accordingly to a smart person, I had to put a lot of thought through the challenges, to solve 'em, some were simple, and some you had to be more experienced and have more "Tools" to work them out. (7/10 = Tough)

												Although confusing, I find it as an attractive puzzle game. The ingame menu is unique, and the gameplay style is extraordinary. Sometimes, you really have to think before your solve. The guns that you retrieve in Antichamber give you abilities to retrieve things like blocks, and can allow you to duplicate them. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												A lovely puzzle game that makes you really think outside the box, Antichamber was a very interesting experience to me. It achieves this strange yet appealing balance with its puzzles by warping our basic perceptions of space. You think there's going to be a floor there? Think again. Added to its minimalistic nature, it was a very enjoyable to play through it and see how far the puzzles would push me.The use of colors is an interesting thing in this game, in that everything is very flat. Mostly, it is black and white, but when there are colors they're colors that vibrantly pop out against the background, like neon green, or cyan blue. It gives a sense of direction at times, as well as keep the player from being visually bored. The colors also aid to accentuate the atmosphere of the game itself. In particular, there was a hallway that I had to walk through that got progressively darker, and while I knew that this game would not have any scares, I was still slightly creeped out by it. The music itself is very ambient, with many natural sounds, so most of the time you will probably feel calm as you solve the puzzles.Speaking of puzzles, you will solve most of the puzzles with a special gun given to you. It allows you to create objects such as blocks to guide your way through an area with a bottomless pit, or as a key to activate a door. However, it is limited in its use in that you need at least one source block of the color in order to use that specific color in the puzzles, and trying to get to that block can be tricky. One puzzle takes you through a hallway filled with a space that destroys any and all blocks you have, but you need to progress with that specific color block. So what do you do? The puzzles for the most part were not too challenging after you get a hang of the mechanics and begin to explore your imagination, though I admit that there were a few that were challenging enough I had to look it up.There is no story to this game. Well...saying that might be a little misleading. There is a story, but it is more like a story that many of us share. Throughout the game little inspirational life messages and lessons are scattered about, usually pertaining to the puzzles. I know some have found these a little pretentious, but I thought they were a nice complement to the task at hand, as well as a good way to reflect on my own life. It is unobtrusive, but they can give you good clues for the puzzles you are working on at the time.Overall, Antichamber was an excellent title that I enjoyed for its minimalistic design as well as puzzle uniqueness. Due to it's rather unique style, I wouldn't recommend this if you're not a really puzzle gamer because the puzzles would only serve to frustrate you. However, if you like doing puzzle platformers or just solving puzzles, I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												Extremely fun puzzle game, with a very different take on the genre. I enetered this game expecting it to be akin to Portal, and while it was in some senses, they are two entirely different experiences. Portal gets you to think with...portals, and Antichamber just simply requires you to think outside the box. While it is a simple concept, some of the challenges can prove to be quite difficult.I really cant find many problems with this game. The only thing that comes to mind is that sometimes the  game can  double up on the solution to puzzles. This is quite noticable around midway through the game, when around 2-3 of the puzzles have the same solution. That being said, the sheer uniqueness of some of the other puzzles more than make up for this. Some may find that the game isn't extremely replayable. However, for me this wasn't too much of a problem, and I thoroughly enjoyed the game even on my second playthrough. Overall, amazing game, an extremely unique game to the genre, and a must-buy during sales.9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2013
												Antichamber has blossomed from an Unreal Tournament 2004 project into a deceptively minimalistic puzzle game. It is an excellent addition to any gaming library thanks to its challenging puzzles and its psychological manipulation of common expectations. While the basic cell-shaded graphics may be down to the game's budget, Antichamber pulls them off brilliantly. Bright primary colours blanket areas where other games might use high quality textures, and interesting particle effects stand out as a visual cue rather than as something to be expected. This adds to the game's poignant art style, as well as making it run smoothly on less capable computers.Antichamber's gameplay mechanics switch between bending the fabric of reality and rule-oriented cube placement. Many puzzles' currencies are doled out as these collectable cubes, with different colours representing possible hints towards a solution. Other puzzles involving movement, physics, and even view orientation are welcome additions that are interspersed regularly. The pacing flows nicely between areas, and each puzzle is unique enough to stay fresh. Rooms that seem inaccessible earlier on will eventually be attainable once new techniques of manipulating cubes are discovered. While this does make for a lot of back-tracking, Antichamber's theme revolves around revisiting the impossible.Aside from teaching the basics of how to utilize its tools, the game leaves interaction with its cubed building-blocks up to the player. The imposed experiential learning leads to many “Eureka!” moments during Antichamber's journey. The game balances them perfectly with some of the more difficult challenges; each solution is just enough of an ego boost to keep spirits high before perplexing players with a new situation. Even the more stupefying tasks never seem arduous, in part because of their basic elegance but also thanks to the omnipresent musical atmosphere.Excellent sound effects are probably the main reason why Antichamber maintains such a calm ambiance. Whether splashing through a shallow pond or standing on a windy mountaintop, the sounds of nature are always present and never get tedious. This contrast between the game's claustrophobic interiors and its superb outdoor soundscape is very mentally stimulating and adds to Antichamber's aloofness. Thankfully, the oddly juxtaposed soundtrack avoids over-complicating itself, which keeps the focus on exploring and solving puzzles.Depending on how thoroughly it's completed, expect this journey to last between eight to twelve hours. Although certain puzzles are inevitably stumping, pulling through them is what makes Antichamber so satisfying to play. Its engrossing atmosphere and frequent instances of disbelief combine to form one of this generation's most appealing puzzle games.

												I really enjoy puzzle games, but oftentimes, they're so inspired by each other that it becomes difficult to find one that really stands out and forces you to think around problems.  That rare sort of innovation is what made Portal such a wonderful game, and the same goes for Antichamber.  It takes some time to get used to wandering around Escher-like rooms, and by the time you think you've got the mechanics figured out, the game throws entirely new challenges at you.The art style, both audio and visual, is a pleasant contrast to the challenging gameplay.  Ambient rainfall or forest sounds accompany bright, contrasting colors, helping keep you calm and focused.  Quite a nice choice for a game like this.If you enjoy games that force you to exercise your reasoning skills, Antihamber is not a game to miss.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
												Antichamber is this borderline experimental game whose only purpose seems to be frustrating intuition-based efforts, and subverting your understanding of space. And if this opening statement sounds enticing albeit annoyingly vague and unhelpful, then it resonates with the philosophy of Antichamber - where almost nothing is as it seems at first glance. Its deceivingly plain aesthetics conceal a devious challenge that may intrigue the casual onlooker for a short time, but which can only be fully conquered through no small amounts of exploration and experimentation. Sometimes you'll get a glimpse of the cogs turning inside the machine as you follow a certain path and earn your access to an entirely optional area. Oftentimes you'll be stumped, and forced to backtrack and consider a different approach. The fascination of Antichamber is in the mystery of its workings. It's a test of your curiosity, cunning, and perhaps most of all your ability to experience the unforeseen and learn from that experience. In the words of Samuel Beckett: "Ever tried. Ever failed. No matter. Try Again. Fail again. Fail better."Antichamber may confuse or even frustrate you, but it's never disappointing. It's a mesmerizing, intricate gem of a game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2013
												If Portal's sense of humor was directed at its environment instead of its narrative.If Obsidian's developers turned their minds towards puzzles instead of point-and-click.Your steps bend space, space bends time, time bends you. The walls expand and contract and rearrange. Your memory is irrelevant, your skills and powers of logic are tested. Your ability to learn from your mistakes is emphasized. Consistency was left behind ages ago.Take the Manipulator. Take the boxes. Find the right way down through the maze, to the food, then find the exit.  Push the exit button.   If the food tastes awful, don't eat it, go back and try another way.They want the same thing that you do, really, they want a path, just like you.  You are in a maze in a maze, but which one counts?  Your maze, their maze, my maze.  Or are the mazes all the same, defined by the limits of their paths?Existence is simple: find the food, push the button, hit the treadmill.But sometimes it gets much harder.  Sometimes the food makes you sick, or you can hear nearby feet racing you, urging you on.  Sometimes the button only gets you landed right back in the beginning of the maze again, and the food won't satisfy.There is only one path and that is the path that you take, but you can take more than one path.Cross over the cell bars, find a new maze, make the maze from it's path, find the cell bars, cross over the bars, find a maze, make the maze from its path, eat the food, eat the path.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Antichamber is a mind-bending puzzler. The closest I can get is "it's like Portal but while tripping on at least 3 different drugs." It defies description. Don't spoil it for yourself, don't watch Let's Plays, don't ask for help, just get it and go. Beat it in one sitting if you can; it's better that way, and assuming you don't go for 100% completion (if there even is such a thing) then it only takes about 4 hours.While some parts of the game can be a pain and some parts will cause headaches, there are only a few puzzles that you *MUST* complete to progress through the game. That said, the more you skip, the harder the remaining puzzles will be.The first time I played it was a spiritual experience. I enjoyed watching some friends struggle through the asinine challenges and watched their minds repeatedly blown. It's a brilliant exercise in thinking so far outside of the box that you escape the bounds of reality and end up back inside the box.And here's a hint: Pay very careful attention. Move slowly and take your time - you'll spot the solutions much more quickly.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												This is one of the toughest thumbs-up decisions I've made.  I bought this game because it looked interesting and different, and had some good reviews.  And it IS interesting.  The word "different," however, does not fully convey the magnitude of its strangeness.This is a game with which I have a love/hate relationship.  I love the concept -- a game that subverts physical rules and creates its own completely bizarre and disorienting (albeit very very minimalist) world.  I love the break from conventional big-name first-person games that do nothing but show you pretty scenery in which you run around and kill people.  And I initially loved the challenge of solving these weird, brain-teasing puzzles.That is, until I started to hate it.  I hate the fact that the gameworld very very frequently loops back on itself and you find yourself solving the same puzzles that you went through quite a while ago.  Perhaps there is a way to play this game so that you avoid all of these loop-back pitfalls; I don't know.  But all too often, I'd fall through a hole that suddenly materializes, or I'd turn a corner, and I'm back at a place that I had passed a long time ago.  This is enough to make me turn off the game in utter frustration.I also hate the save-game mechanics, which are completely checkpoint-based and not controllable by the player, and do NOT let you save  wherever you want to save.  The checkpoints are too far apart, for one thing.  For another, because of the way that the game loops back on itself, and the fact that the gameworld is so completely disorienting anyway, these checkpoints are rendered fairly useless.  So I'm back at this weird eye in the wall.  For the 29th time.  Except something might be a bit different about it this time around.  You see the problem here?This game is like a practical joke on the player.  Still, after these long periods of utter frustration and downtime (quitting the game in disgust), after a few days or a week there is a strange compulsion to give it another go.  To see if any progress can be made THIS TIME.  It's masochistic in a way.  The fascinating, mindbending puzzles keep calling me back, my frustration with the game notwithstanding. I have not finished this game yet, not sure if I'll even be compelled to make it that far.  We'll see.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												This is an interesting game to say the least.  To say that you have to think outside of the box to solve the puzzles presented in this game is an understatement.  Because the entire environment of the game exists in non-euclidian space there is no box to begin with, at the very least not a box in the normal sense. . .At it's heart Antichamber is about discovery: discover what is possible in the game, discover a little bit about the creators, discover a little about yourself, discover what freedom is when you don't have to worry about directions.I will let you know that there will be a lot of times you will be stuck.  Stuck with no hope at all of getting anywhere.  Stuck with no idea how you got there and no way of heading back.  The esc key is your friend.  At any time you can hit esc and jump into the lobby of the game.  From this lobby you can pick any point you've already been to to restart your adventure.  Also here, you can view all the pictures and sayings you've gathered over your exploration.Explore, think, discover, and have some fun in the process.And maybe eventually I'll make it to that blasted end!

content:
